bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 17, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Reed a copy of a talk he has given at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College. He mentions the possibility of visiting her later. He also inquires as to whom she might have given some of her husband's letters, especially those from October 1900 to January 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 17, 1941
div1.opener:
To Mrs Walter Reed
June 17, 1941
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I certainly appreciated having your nice letter expressing your
interest in the talk which I gave in Cleveland at the unveiling of the
painting, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. As I have written your daughter,
I can only assure you that my tribute to your husband and his colleagues was
a most sincere one. I have spent much time studying this story, have visited
many of the survivors and have visited Cuba twice.

By separate post I am sending you a copy of the talk given by me
at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson
College, last October. You will forgive me, I am sure, for emphasizing the
work of Lazear on that particular occasion since you will understand that it
was given at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial. It is my hope to be able
to write a full and complete story of the work of all those connected with
the marvelous conquest of yellow fever. To that end I gratefully accepted
the invitation of your daughter to visit you and her at some time in the
near future. I do not believe that I will be able to get East again until
some time next Fall but I hope to visit Washington to see General Ireland
and General Kean again and to look up some of your husband's records in the
Surgeon General's office. Perhaps then, if it is convenient for you, I
might run up to pay you a brief visit for a couple of hours.

I asked your daughter if she knew to whom you had given various
letters of your husband. I have learned more from some of his letters than
from many other sources and regret indeed that the letters which your daughter
allowed me contain very few references, for example, to the month of October,
1900 and to January, 1901. If you remember at least the names of some of the
physicians and institutions to which you sent these letters, I would be very
glad indeed to write to at least some of them and get copies of them. Already
I have acquired quite a lot of material. Dr. Kelly of Baltimore, whom I visited
last month, most graciously handed over his whole collection of material to me
and General Kean has given me much help as has General Truby. My sole purpose
in this labor of love is to present to the world a comprehensive and adequate
story that will add to the glory of all those concerned with this conquest.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
